Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating gene and individual level selection to understand the evolution of self-fertilization in flowering plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout the biosphere, most organisms display some sort of adaptation to reduce inbreeding. In flowering plants alone, there are a staggering number of adaptations that prevent inbreeding, yet these systems break down frequently. Mutations causing self-pollination should enjoy two major selective advantages. Mutations causing self-pollination will spread in nature either because they enjoy a gene-level transmission advantage or because they boost seed production when pollination is uncertain. No study has simultaneously tested these mechanisms and evaluated their interaction, so it is not well understood why outcross-pollination mechanisms repeatedly break down. In this project, a mutation causing self-pollination will be crossed into a typically outcross-pollinated genome and replicated field experiments will examine whether this mutation spreads because of genetic or ecological reasons.
This project will identify the mechanisms that cause evolutionary shifts to inbreeding, which imperil plant biodiversity. The project will train undergraduate and graduate students to use genetic markers to infer parentage and patterns of gene flow, which are critical tools in applied agricultural settings. Students will present their results at public outreach events coordinated by the Center for Cedar Glades Studies (CCGS) in Tennessee. The involvement of students in the process of direct outreach will communicate the principles of evolution and conservation biology to the public. The PIs will also work with science educators at the CCGS to develop a pollination ecology field exercise aimed at K-12 students to be included in the "Cedar Glades Activity Guide" published by the CCGS and used by many local science teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A repeated trend in flowering plants is for the evolution of self-fertilization from the outcrossing condition. The purpose of this grant was to study the outcome of natural selection on a mutation for selfing in natural populations. Using this setup, it was possible to determine whether the evolution of selfing is determined by ecological factors (i.e. pollinators), genetic costs (i.e. expression of harmful mutations), or some combination of thereof -- regardless, the work sheds light on the most important factors driving a major evolutionary trend in nature.

In terms of the intellectual merits of the research, perhaps the most important finding of the research is that selfing mutations should not spread all the time in cases where they increase seed production. This constraint emerges because selfing involves major costs -- while making a few extra selfed seeds is clearly advantageous, this is not the case when such a switch causes plants to lose the possibility of producing high-quality outcrossed seeds. Such profound fitness costs may help to explain why outcrossing persists in plants, even in the face of inadequate pollinator services. Another important component of the work involved a global survey of plant breeding systems, which found that the ability to self is elevated in island environments. 

In terms of broader impacts, the grant yielded 12 published papers and 6 oral presentations at national scientific meetings. Much of the funding supported the professional development and research of graduate students and a postdoc as they lbecame increasingly independent and proficient scientists. In particular, funding supported 1 post-doc, 3 graduate students (1 MS, 2 PhD), and 6 undergraduate students. Overall, this work involved 6 female and 4 male individuals. Perhaps most importantly, graduate and undergraduate students were trained in basic molecular biology (e.g. PCR, electrophoresis, sequencing), controlled pollinations, line cross analyses, and the dynamic feedback between theory and empirical research. These skills are valuable in any scientific enterprise and helped 2 students to continue their educations beyond the undergraduate level in medical school.
